ygData.subject: Re: Is AHNI the only java hyperneat implementation?

Hi Ron, I'm also not aware of any other Java implementations of HyperNEAT=
 right now.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Oliver Coleman <oliver.colem=
an@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ron,
> 
> I'm the author of AHNI. As far as I know AH=
NI is the only Java
> implementation of HyperNEAT. Experiments typically us=
e parameters given in
> a .properties file (which is given as an argument w=
hen running AHNI). It
> would be easy to write a fitness function class tha=
t reads input and output
> examples from files specified in the properties =
file. See
> com.anji.objectrecognition. ObjectRecognitionFitnessFunction3.j=
ava for an
> example to get started.
> 
> I'm currently writing a new versi=
on of AHNI that will implement extensions
> such as ES-HyperNEAT, allow usi=
ng the Bain neural network simulator (
> https://github.com/OliverColeman/b=
ain ), and will be refactored to make the
> code a bit neater. It's on gith=
ub but may not be stable or working just yet.
> 
> Cheers,
> Oliver
> On Se=
p 30, 2012 4:44 AM, "roncking2001" <roncking@...> wrote:
> 
> > **
> >
> >
=
> > Hi All,
> >
> > I want a java version of hyperneat. AHNI appears to hav=
e to examples that
> > are 'hard coded' in java classes, and I want somethi=
ng that can do new
> > experiments where the input and output come from fil=
es instead. I'm
> > especially wanting to do more vision experiments.
> >
>=
 > Is there any other implementations out there?
> >
> > Regards,
> >
> > R=
on
> >
> >  
> >
>
